comment._content: There are plaques on the bridge parapet, one each side, but I can't read them on Google Streetview Squinting, those look like "In memory of..." plaques, not dedications.

comment._content: OK, one is a Hunger Strike memorial.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/86346290@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Is it not more likely to be this bridge? maps.google.ie/maps?q=Fassaugh+Lane+in+Cabra,+Dublin&...

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Carlisle steam cranes. Built by Cowans Sheldon from 1920.[http://www.flickr.com/photos/cork_trains/8537932130/in/photostream]

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] I added a note highlighting a terrace of houses on a hill with a stepped roofline: I'm pretty sure that's St. Attracta Road near the bridge [http://www.flickr.com/photos/86346290@N00] identified.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
I can't find anything definitive, but I don't think that St. Attracta's Road is as early as 1936 - more likely to be in the 1940s, making this maybe 10 years later than advertised.

Also, many roads called "Lane" in Dublin were renamed "Avenue" at some stage as Lane was thought to sound a bit rough. So Fassaugh Lane is more likely to be Fassaugh Avenue than Fassaugh Road.

Hmm, maybe not, the OS 25" marks the road at [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06]'s bridge as Fassaugh Lane...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Niall you are more than likely correct

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: There are several entries for housing schemes in Cabra in the DIA: 298 houses in 1930, 76 in 1932, 289 houses in 1933, Cabra West in 1940.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: So the references I see to Cabra housing dating from the 40s are probably wrong. Lots of it is early 30s, and it was presumably this development which led to rebuilding the bridge, so 1936 does seem possible.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I am 100% with you now.

sorry for the confusion.

comment._content: There are several pictures with this title in the nli archive, but all the others are labelled June 1939, which matches the children's clothes better.
